awd_titl_txt: Biotechnology Unified Education Network of Opportunities Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This project plans to build a Biotechnology Unified Education Network of Opportunities (BUENO) in the Lower Rio Grande Valley that will offer a clear path for undergraduates into careers in biotechnology-based STEM fields.  The project includes three major activities: 1) curriculum and educational materials development; 2) professional development for educators; and 3) program development and improvement. The main goal of the BUENO Project is to build the first biotechnology program in the region to enhance the employability of technicians in biotechnology-related fields.  The BUENO Project has the potential to provide a framework that can be duplicated at other minority 2- year and 4-year community colleges and universities. Moreover, through the partnership between Texas Southmost College and local school districts, the Project can build sustained efforts to align college readiness and the college curriculum in biotechnological fields of study. This alignment can help to ensure preparation of employees to meet the community's workforce demands.
 
Through the BUENO Project, Texas Southmost College aims to increase student learning by developing a new biotechnology program of study, providing professional development for teacher improvement, and offering the most up-to-date curriculum and educational materials possible. Data collected as part of the evaluation plan will be critical for identifying strategies and activities that can be modified to improve project outcomes and student learning, as well as student and instructor competency and confidence, especially at a Hispanic-Serving Institution. Furthermore, the BUENO Project contribute new curricular materials that will be especially useful at minority institutions, as well as insight concerning which activities and interventions are most effective in promoting the success of Hispanics and veterans in biotechnology and related STEM fields.  These contributions will add to the body of knowledge about effective science education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2018, Texas Southmost College (TSC) was awarded an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) grant, ?Biotechnology Unified Education Network of Opportunities (BUENO).? The aim of the project was to use existing ties between TSC, local school districts, and four-year institutions to build the first biotechnology program in the Lower Rio Grande Valley (LRGV) of Texas. Such a program could then expand biotechnology in the local economy by enhancing the employability of biotechnology technicians. TSC is a Hispanic-Serving Institution with a student body is over 90% Hispanic.

 

Professional development activities included summer teacher workshops and on-going mentorship of dual credit instructors. Two summer workshops (2018) and (2019) trained 3 and 19 local high school and middle school teachers, respectively, in lab biotechnology lab activities, including best practices for implementing in their classroom. In 2018, three dual credit instructors, representing three high schools from Brownsville Independent School District were recruited and received ongoing mentoring to adapt curricular materials and implement biotechnology activities in their biology labs. They became the core ?BUENO Team? and helped design the subsequent teacher workshop, summer camps, and additional biotechnology activities. A fourth dual credit teacher from the same school district participated in 2021-22. The majority of participants in teacher workshops and all who received mentoring were Hispanic.

 

Biotechnology lab activities were planned and implemented in Biology lab courses for science majors at the TSC campus and local early college high schools offering dual credit through TSC. In the 2018-2019 school year, 162 students (51 at three high schools and 111 on the TSC campus) experienced three new, biotechnology-related lab activities, two in Biology I Lab for science majors and one in the Biology II labs. In 2019-2020 school year, by the time COVID-19 forced remote instruction, the team had settled on four new activities for Biology I lab and two for Biology II. During remote instruction, we found online alternatives or focused on data analysis. In all 306 students experienced the Biology I labs and 232 the Biology II labs from Fall 2019 through Summer 2021. During the pandemic, TSC adopted Open Educational Resources-based curriculum for the Biology for Science Major courses, including the four biotechnology lab activities in Biology I and one of the two in Biology II. From Fall 2021 -Spring 2023, a total of 406 students experienced the Biology I labs and 434 the Biology II labs, including students at five early college high schools in mainly face-to-face instruction. In 2019, dual credit students were surveyed about their Biology I experience, 33% stated they would consider studying biotechnology after their experiences. In 2021, students on the TSC campus were given the same survey, 47% indicated that they would consider biotechnology careers.

 

The BUENO Project team implemented a course-based research program called SEA-PHAGES in campus sections of theses introductory biology lab courses that replaced most of the biotechnology-related labs. The program focuses on authentic research in which students isolate and characterize viruses that infect bacteria from soil samples they collected. Many of the lab skills they learned are basic techniques in biotechnology/bioscience labs. Students were also told their work could have applications in biotechnology. The majority, 62.5%, of students who answered a survey conducted by the project evaluator at the end of the first course in Fall 2022 responded that they would consider further study or a career in biotechnology. Comparing these students to the campus students in 2021, who experienced more traditional labs, may be an indication that course-based research experiences are important to encouraging students to pursue STEM careers in a predominantly Hispanic population. The project has also designed a two-year degree plan in Biotechnology with a related one-year certificate. The SEA-PHAGES program is embedded in the lab curriculum of the first two courses.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2023
Modified by: Regina D Overath
